trans-unit.source: Calculates statistical formulas.
Formulas can be loosely grouped into the following categories: distributions, including inverse distributions; tests; and basic statistical formulas.
Each group has common characteristics with respect to their input and return values.
The Anova formula determines the existence or absence of a statistically significant difference between the mean values of two or more groups of data.
Alpha value.
The acceptable input range is between 0 and 1.
Names of two or more input series.
Each series must exist in the series collection at the time of the method call, and have the same number of data points.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.AnovaResult"></xref> object.
The beta function calculates the beta function value.
First value for the beta function.
Second value for the beta function.
Beta value.
The correlation formula shows the strength of the relationship that exists between two random variables.
The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
Correlation value between the two groups of data.
The covariance formula measures the degree of dependence that may exist between two random variables.
The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
Covariance value between the two groups of data.
The F distribution formula calculates the probability for the F-distribution.
The F value for which you want the distribution.
First degree of freedom.
Second degree of freedom.
Probability for the F distribution.
The F-test formula performs a two-sample F-test using F distribution, and is used to see if the samples have different variances.
The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
The alpha value.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.FTestResult"></xref> object.
The gamma function calculates the gamma value.
Value for which the gamma value is required.
Gamma value.
The inverse F distribution formula calculates the inverse of the F cumulative distribution.
Probability for the F distribution.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
First degree of freedom.
Second degree of freedom.
F value for the F distribution.
The inverse normal distribution formula calculates the inverse of the standard normal cumulative distribution.
The distribution has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of one.
Alpha value.
The acceptable input range is between 0 and 1.
Inverse of the normal distribution function.
The inverse *t*-distribution formula calculates the *t*-value of the Student's *t*-distribution as a function of probability and degrees of freedom.
Probability for the F distribution.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Degree of freedom.
Inverse of the *t*-distribution.
The mean formula calculates the average, or mean, of data stored in a data series.
If named input series does not exist in the <xref:System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.SeriesCollection> at the time of the method call, an exception is thrown.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the data for which the mean value is required.
Mean value of all the data points in the given series.
The median formula calculates the median of the data stored in a data series.
If the named input series does not exist in the <xref:System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.SeriesCollection> at the time of the method call, an exception is thrown.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the data for which the median value is required.
Median of all the data points in the given series.
The normal distribution formula calculates the value of the standard normal cumulative distribution.
The distribution has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
Value for which the normal distribution is required.
Value of the standard normal cumulative distribution.
The *t*-distribution formula calculates the probability for the Student's *t*-distribution.
t-value for which you want the distribution.
Degree of freedom
If set to `true`, one-tailed distribution is used.
Otherwise, two-tailed distribution is used.
*t*-distribution function probability.
The *t*-test with equal variances formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with equal variances.
Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult"></xref> object.
The *t*-test paired formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with paired samples.
This is useful when there is an observed natural pairing in samples (for example, when a sample group is tested twice).
Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult"></xref> object.
The *t*-test with unequal variances formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with unequal variances.
Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult"></xref> object.
The variance formula calculates the variance within a group of data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the data for which the mean value is required.
Specify `true` if the data is a sample of a population; and `false` if the data is the entire population.
Variance within the group of data.
The Z-test formula performs a Z-test using normal distribution.
Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Variance within the first group of data.
Variance within the second group of data.
Alpha value.
The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.Chart.Series"></xref> object that stores the second group's data.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.ZTestResult"></xref> object.
